metadata.title: Top 26 Data Science YouTube Channels you should subscribe to in 2020 [Updated 2021] | by Benedict Neo | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Top 26 Data Science YouTube Channels you should subscribe to in 2020 [Updated 2021]

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Some of the best videos found we’ve found on YouTube.
Intro to Data Science with R
Data Science, Machine Learning Engineering Hot Topics
5 Tips for Getting a Data Science Job [INTERVIEW]
Data analysis in Python with pandas
How to get a job in tech
How to Become a Data Scientist (You Don’t Need College)
How to Kickstart Your Software Engineering Career

all_paragraphs: YouTube is a great platform for both entertainment and education. The best thing about it is, there isn’t a 10 dollar per month subscription to watching videos on Youtube, it’s all free for you to watch. Except for the only currency, you pay for watching them is your time, and what you decide to watch is entirely up to you. The thing about YouTube is if you know how to use it wisely, valuing your time and being aware of the videos you watch, you actually gain something useful from it that adds value to your life. That’s a concept called opportunity cost.

“There is an opportunity cost for everything we do. This is why we must have the awareness to ensure that what we are pursuing is really what we value, because the pursuit leaves countless lost opportunities in its wake. We choose one experience at the sacrifice of all other experiences.” — Chris Matakas

Data Science online courses with questionable prices are flooding the internet, most of which are not credible and are just a marketing strategy. Instead of scouring the internet, why not go to YouTube? YouTube a great platform to learn because of its ability to visualize complex topics. If you were to learn about NLP, would you read a book about it or watch a seasoned programmer explain it to you with code and intuitive examples? I myself would prefer the latter.

Although YouTube suffers from similar issues of clickbait videos, there are some really good gems in the platform with resourceful people practically giving away tutorials and courses for free. So in this article, I will be sharing these gems that create the best videos on Data Science, whether its advice, coding tutorials, projects, etc.

With Covid-19 keeping everyone in their homes, this is the perfect opportunity to start learning something new, and why not make that Data Science? A field that is booming and is playing a huge role in society. Instead of reading it up from a book, follow these YouTubers and gain insights and advice from their years of experience in the field. Plus you can learn how to code by following through their tutorials and pick up a new skill.
So, fire up YouTube in the next tab and subscribe to these YouTubers below!

Talking about Youtube Channels, TDS has its very own youtube channel! Through that platform, they bring the best quality content on Data Science, which includes interviews, work-life, new tools, etc. TDS is the biggest Data Science publication on Medium, so why not check them out at YouTube and see what they’re up to there!
Favorite Playlist: Some of the best videos found we’ve found on YouTube.
Tech With Tim is a brilliant programmer who teaches about Python, Game Development with Pygame, Java and Machine Learning. He creates top-notch coding tutorials on Python.
Favorite Playlist: Python with Machine Learning tutorial.

Sentdex creates one of the best Python Programming tutorials on YouTube. His tutorials span from complete beginners, going further than just the basics. Learn about machine learning, finance, data analysis, robotics, web development, game development and more. Check out his latest video on the Covid-19 Kaggle challenge
Favorite Playlist: Machine Learning with Python

Corey Schafer creates tutorials for programmers and developers, covering topics from beginner to advanced levels. Various topics such as Python, SQL, JavaScript, Git, as well as tips and tricks are covered to help you in your career. Corey’s videos are

Python Programmer is a YouTuber who delivers, you guessed it, python-related content. His content includes tutorials on Python, Data Science, Machine Learning, Book recommendations and so on. If you need help with learning Python, he’s the man that will help you.
Keith Galli is a recent MIT Graduate. He makes educational videos on Computer Science, Programming, Board Games, and more.
Favorite Playlist: Python Pandas Data Science

David Langer’s channel publishes brilliant videos on every aspect of Data Science. His videos cover the entire lifecycle of a Data Mining project — data wrangling, data exploration, data cleaning, data visualization, data analysis, feature engineering, and machine learning. The main programming language taught is the R programming language and he touches on the many libraries involved such as ggplot2, randomForest, and rpart.
Favorite Playlist: Intro to Data Science with R

Andreas Kretz is a Data engineer and the founder of Plumbers of Data Science. To him, data engineering is all about ingesting, processing and storing data to aid Data Scientists to do what they do best. In his channel, he does live streams, tutorials on how to get hands-on experience in data engineering, and Q&A videos about data engineering with Hadoop, Kafka, Spark, and so on.
Favorite Playlist: Data Engineering online courses

FreeCodeCamp is an amazing non-profit organization and open-source community that a collection of resources that helps people learn to code for free and build their own projects. Their website is completely free for anyone to learn about coding and they have their own news platform that shares articles on programming as well as projects.

The Springboard YouTube channel publishes interviews with Data Scientists from top companies such as Google, Uber, Airbnb, etc. From these videos, you can get a glimpse of what it’s like to be a data scientist and acquire invaluable advice to apply in your life.
Favorite Playlist: Data Science, Machine Learning Engineering Hot Topics

Data Science Dojo is a channel that is committed to teaching data science to everyone. They are committed to stripping the complexity of data science and presenting it in a form that is easier to swallow. In this channel, you can find myriads of tutorials, talks, and courses on data engineering and science.

CS Dojo is founded by YK Sug, a Toronto-based software developer and data scientist with experience at various software companies, including Google and Microsoft. He makes videos about programming and computer science.
Favorite Video: 5 Tips for Getting a Data Science Job [INTERVIEW]

365 Data Science is a channel committed to helping data science enthusiasts who are stuck when it comes to qualifications and credibility. This channel hopes to help those who want to become data scientists be fully prepared and kickstart their careers.
Favorite Playlist: Data Science Career in 2020
Edureka is an e-learning platform with tons of tutorials and walkthroughs on topics such as python, R, machine learning, data science and etc.
Favorite Playlist: Machine Learning Tutorial in Python

Data School is founded by Kevin Markham. He is committed to helping beginners learn the right things and focus on the topics they need to master first. His channel encompasses top-notch tutorials that are for all skill levels. Kevin has teaching experience using Python in both physical classes and online.
Favorite Playlist: Data analysis in Python with pandas

DataCamp’s channel promotes full-fledged tutorials that helps students learn and acquire skills from the world’s top data scientists. They advocate the principle of applying what the students learn immediately after each lesson, ensuring retention and understanding of the topic at hand.
DataDash is a channel with all things related to cryptocurrencies, data analytics & science, and detecting global trends with the latest analysis techniques.
Favorite Playlist: SQL & Data Analytics for Beginners

Chanin Nantasenamat, or a.k.a the Data Professor is an Associate Professor of Bioinformatics at a research university where he runs a research laboratory that utilizes data science for uncovering the hidden knowledge of big data in medicine. Through his channel, he delivers outstanding content explaining concepts, tutorials, as well as answering questions about big data. His main goal is to help students and enthusiasts learn about data science and to have the ability to make sense of data.

3blue1brown, created by Grant Sanderson, is the best visualizer of mathematics on YouTube, period. His goal is to use animation to explain to the viewer complex mathematical concepts in hopes of helping them see things from a different perspective, and have a deeper appreciation for the concepts.

Joma Tech is YouTuber who makes videos to help people to get into the tech industry. He has experienced the life of working at big tech companies as a data scientist and software engineer. With that experience, he makes videos on interviews with experts, lifestyle in silicon valley, as well as making data science more approachable.
Favorite video: What is Data Science?

Matt Tran gives an insight into the real world and talks to the people working in the field to give you an unfiltered reality of what it takes to become a data scientist, what it’s like to work as one, as well as details like salary and hobbies.
Favorite video: How to get a job in tech
Favorite playlist: How to Become a Data Scientist (You Don’t Need College)

Jordan Harrod is a graduate student at Harvard and MIT researching brain-machine interfaces and machine learning for medicine. She has always fascinated by the way AI is being integrated into our lives, from social media to the military. In her channel, she explores the way we humans interact with Ai and algorithms, and their uses in our everyday life. Jordan is great at conveying complex topics such as AI to the mass audience and makes it easier to understand. Check out her playlist on AI!

Ken Jee has been in the data science field doing sports analytics for the last 5 years and has worked in companies ranging from startups to fortune 100 organizations. When he first started learning Data science, he found that there were very few resources to learn from, so as a way of giving back to society, he is making videos on YouTube to share his experiences and to help others break into the field. I just recently found out about Ken Jee and his channel is very informative and resourceful, be sure to check him out!
Favorite video: How I learned Data Science

Statistics can be a very challenging topic, which is one of the reasons why Data Science can be difficult to learn. Concepts such as stochastic processes and Statistical limit theory can be hard to digest. That’s where StatQuest comes for the rescue, with his amazing videos, he breaks down major methodologies into easy to digest pieces. Most importantly, he doesn’t dumb down the topics but instead, make you smarter and up your Statistics game. Check him out today!

Jabrils is just a guy who knows very little but wants to know a lot, as said in his bio. His videos mainly compromise of the use of AI for different applications, such as making an AI app to save lives and programming an AI drone to follow him. He also makes videos on programming.

Mayuko worked for six years as a Senior iOS Software Engineer in Silicon Valley companies like Intuit, Patreon, and Netflix. Right now, she works full-time on content creating primarily on YouTube that helps her viewers break into the tech industry. Her videos also touch on lifestyle, career, and tech advice as well as topics such as cultural identity and imposter syndrome. Check out her playlist on starting a SE career!
Favorite playlist: How to Kickstart Your Software Engineering Career

The Data Science Salon is a unique vertical focused data science conference which grew into a diverse community of senior data science, machine learning and other technical specialists. They gather face-to-face and virtually to educate each other, illuminate best practices and innovate new solutions in a casual atmosphere.

Their YouTube channel features selected insights for data science practitioners and managers who want to acquire new skills casually. Recently, they released two tracks (a technical and a business) where they have started to release 2 videos (full sessions) every week, including best practices and insights of applying AI and ML to different verticals.
These videos featured were previously only accessible to members of a paid membership so go check them out now!

Don’t let staying at home and the agony of it cause any internal discomfort, which is the underpinning factor for why we are always distracted. The truth is, we want to be distracted. Instead of binging the latest Netflix show 10 hours straight, why not try learning on YouTube? Learning Data Science today is a great return of investment (ROI) of your time and effort because data will just keep growing exponentially, and the ability to find meaning out of data will be indispensable. So, subscribe to these channels and check out their videos to pick up a marketable skill or learn something new.
To make sure you get the most out of learning on YouTube, here are some tips and tricks:
I hope you found this article useful and your journey towards learning Data Science and becoming an awesome data scientist is easier. To end, let me present you with this quote on visual learning.
“It has been said that 80 percent of what people learn is visual.”
Thank you for reading and God Bless.
Check out my other articles here!
If you want to be updated with my latest articles follow me on Medium.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
I write Data Science tutorials and share the best resources for learning
